comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content:
Taken by Pall Mall Gazette journalist Henry Norman the day after Widow MacNamara's eviction. The first sheriff, called McMahon, had turned up with a large force several days earlier but had epileptic fit and the police withdrew. The tenants saw this as divine intervention and made this effigy of him.

Incidentally the title was attributed by Norman to a photo he took of Michael Davitt and two priests, full term: "the firebrands, lay and clerical".

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
The Bodyke evictions have been well and truly covered in other posts and on other shots.  You can just see Canon Hannon in this one, he was very much the ringleader though he insisted on no violence and intervened when he felt the tenants were getting too hot under the collar.
Great shot and a very interesting story!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Sorry, Sean. Don't mean to be a slave driver - just having a good old tidy up, and was astonished that there'd never been a comment on this one.  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 35727396@N03
comment._content: Good for Canon Hannon and the gallant parishioners. Nice to hear one of these events had a happier ending. I only discovered your site whilst sweeping around Flickr. I spent four hours looking through your wonderful library yesterday. I really enjoyed your photographs and I admire your many contributors in tracking down locations and people. This adds so much more colour and interest to the old images. Thank you all.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35727396@N03] Thank you. Our contributors are indeed worthy of admiration. They're absolutely amazing (and amusing!) every day.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/99002941@N08] Thank you for the date. If taken the day after Widow McNamara's eviction, then it had to be Friday, 3 June 1887.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Is this Canon Hannon or Fr. Murphy? Same clerical gentleman appears in this photo of the Widow McNamara's eviction, and is middle aged-ish. Journalist Henry Norman describes Hannon as "a splendid young athlete".
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] More then likely it is Murphy, there is a sketch of him in Norman's book on the Bodyke evictions. The date is a pretty educated guess, he was reported by several papers to be there the day before MacNamara was evicted, having made several photos of the tenants' preparations.
